pages.text: Bull Terriers have two genes that affect how they look, the B Locus and the W Locus. The B Locus determines whether the dog has red or black fur, while the W Locus determines the extent of the dog's white markings.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates red fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the red trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for red pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either red carriers or red puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The W Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'W' and recessive 'w'. The 'W' allele creates high amounts of white fur, while the 'w' allele keeps white markings to a minimum. Dogs with two copies of 'W' will have completely white fur, while dogs with two copies of 'w' will have smaller white markings. Dogs with one copy of each will have high amounts of white markings and show their base color.
